distorOrdPrc.ordInstr: Data is available to customers via one time, quarterly and monthly updates. The general public must acquire this data from the Information Services Branch of the AER. To place an order, email informationrequest@aer.ca with the following information: * contact information (name, address, and telephone number), * product name and format, and * any other information required in the “request by” field. http://www1.aer.ca/ProductCatalogue/ordering.html

rpCntInfo.cntInstr: For General Inquiries Contact the Customer Contact Centre at: Phone: 403-297-8311 Toll-free: 1-855-297-8311 For Product Services Section: Phone: (403) 297-8311 select 2

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This dataset contains oil and gas pipelines in the Province of Alberta that have been applied for to the AER. This dataset excludes low pressure distribution lines and some pipelines under 0.05km that were not added at the time of the dataset creation.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: This dataset is intended for mapping purposes and represents the best information available to the AER at the date of publication. Specific pipeline location information should be obtained from the survey plans, owners and field observation.

themeKeys.keyword: Pipeline, Operating, Permitted, Discontinued, Abandoned, Removed

LegConsts.othConsts: The general public must acquire this data from the Information Services Branch of the AER.

LegConsts.othConsts: Users of the AER data files are permitted to use the files to select and process data for internal or client use and to release copies of small portions of the files on computer media, that result from specialized retrievals, to their clients; copying of a complete file or a large portion of a file for resale is not permitted.

dataLineage.statement: This Enhanced Pipline Product dataset represents the license status, location, licensee of record and other basic information for all the Pipelines across the Province of Alberta. This data is extracted from the AER's database FC_Pipeline_Licence_Segment, containing information provided by industry, and merged with a master attribute table to create 2 Enhanced_PL_Product shapefiles in the GCS_NAD83 and NAD83_10TM_AEPForest projections. These pipelines are licensed by the AER and have been positioned according to AER records.

prcStep.stepDesc: The following description provides a chronological account (from 1983 to the present) of how the AER evolved the mapping of the pipelines it has received in applications. Date: Until 1983: Pipeline locations reported to AER on as-built drawings. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high and low pressure pipelines throughout the Province of Alberta (both AER and NEB regulated lines). Provincial pipeline data set drafted on linens. In support of map readability, pipelines were moved from their actual location, but parallel to existing pipelines in the same right-of-way. Date: 1983 - 1989: Provincial pipeline linen based data set digitized into a drawing system. Pipeline locations reported via as-built drawings. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout the Province of Alberta (both AER and NEB regulated lines). In support of map readability, pipelines were moved from their actual location, but parallel to existing lines in the same right-of-way. Low pressure lines under 700 kPa maximum operating pressure. Date: 1990 - 2002: Provincial digital data set geo-referenced to a cartesian grid. As-built plan submissions no longer required to be submitted with applications. Industry reported planned locations of the pipeline(s) in a base map drawing or sketch. Accuracy was limited to the quarter section(s) intersected by the pipeline. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout the Province of Alberta (both AER and NEB regulated lines). In support of map readability, parallel pipelines were moved. Date: 2003-2007: Data imported into an ESRI ArcGIS geo-database. Conversion process not 100% clean. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout Alberta (both AER and NEB regulated lines), In support of map readability, parallel pipelines were moved. Technicians stopped digitizing pipelines less than 50 meters in length, except those containing sour gas and those that were the only line pertaining to the license. Technicians began digitizing pipelines based on the direction of the flow of material inside the pipe. There is no attribute describing which pipelines are digitized based on flow direction. Date: 2008: From January 1, 2008, EUB split into the AER and AUC, AUC now submitting construction plans to the AER for inclusion into the AER pipeline data set. No net change in the pipelines included in the data set. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure locations throughout the Province of Alberta ( AER, AUC and NEB regulated lines). The AER will continue to maintain these lines in our pipeline dataset because we have a MOU with the AUC to provide surveillance and monitoring on these lines (Inspections and incident response). These lines are identifiled by the LICENSEES---ATCO Gas and Pipelines Ltd. (0144) and AltaGas Utilities Inc. (0190). The NEB lines (80000 licence) within our dataset (aprox. 5000km) are not regulated by the AER. Date: 2009: Industry submitted construction plans that include the intended location of the pipeline and intended right-of-way. Technicians digitized the pipelines and updated the location of surrounding pipelines impacted by the new or updated application. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout the Province of Alberta (AER, AUC and NEB regulated lines). In support of map readability, parallel lines were moved. From April 29, 2009, the 25,000 km of NGTL (NOVA) pipelines were transferred to the NEB for regulation, monitoring and surveillance under the '80000' number set. Prior to this the ERCB was the regulator and was responsible for monitoring and surveillance of the pipelines, as a result before this date, NGTL have to be included in the dataset, and excluded after April 29, 2009. Date: 2010: AER stops maintaining NEB pipelines. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout the Province of Alberta (AER and AUC regulated lines). Date: 2011: Industry submitted electronic (PDF) construction plans, technician's geo-referenced these documents, then digitized the pipeline(s) in the application. The use of the Rural Cadastral and DIDS data sets were also used to support the creation of the pipelines. Pipeline data compiled to support the production of a set of maps depicting high pressure pipeline locations throughout the Province of Alberta (AER and AUC regulated lines). In support of map readability, parallel pipelines were moved. Digitize all pipelines applied for, including those less than 50 meters in length. Date: 2015: From September 1, 2015 pipelines with a status marked as removed are included in the dataset and attributed as such. Date: 2016: From October 1, 2016, pipelines with “removal” status will be removed from the dataset if the AER receives a letter verifying the removal of the pipeline, otherwise the pipelines will be included in the dataset with the status of “removal.” Date: 2017: From June 16, 2017 the AER introduced the collection of pipelines in a digital spatial data format. The line data submitted is to fall within the surveyed right of way. The point data is to fall within the correct LSD. The AER mapping technicians no longer edit this data. Industry reported the geometry source of the data as: as-planned, construction, centre of right-of-way or as-built. The AER denotes all legacy mapping data with a geometry source of 'mapping'. Pipeline tie-ins are no longer maintaned by the AER. Date: 2017: From June 28, 2017 the Enhanced Pipeline dataset includes new attributes that were added to ensure the dataset contains the same attributes as those in OneStop. New include H2S Release Volume, H2S Release Level, Bidirectional Pipeline Ind, HDD Bored Ind, Liner Grade, Liner Type, External Coating, Pipeline Environment, Pipeline Class Location, Substance 1, Substance 2 and Substance 3. For Pipeline Amendments, completed through OneStop, where the amendment is a status change, there will be a 24 hour lag between what is visble in OneStop and what is visible in the Enhanced Pipeline Dataset.

enttyp.enttypd: This dataset contains all oil and gas pipelines in the Province of Alberta that have been applied for to the AER. This dataset excludes low pressure distribution lines.

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
Internal Feature Number
The pipeline licence number
Indicates if pipeline is properity of the National Energy Board (NEB-80000 series)
A number identifying a pipline segment with the same engineering specifications for a given license
A concatenation of Licence_Number and Segment_Line_Number to make a specific line segment unique.
Length of feature in internal units.

Unique identifier for a particular pipeline segment. This unique surrogate identifier is required to properly support licence transfers since the segment licence number and line number can change between licences.
Name of the business associate, usually the legal name. A business associate's name can change over time.
A business associate code obtained from Petrinex (Canada's Petroleum Information Network) that identifies licensees, agents or any company that does business with the AER (ie. drilling companies)
Identifies a set of pipeline specifications which apply to one or more licensed pipeline segments.
Length of the segment in kilometers, submitted by the applicant.
The operating status of the line

edom.edomvd: The permanent deactivation of a pipeline done in a manner that ensures the pipeline is left in a permanently safe and secure condition.
The temporary deactivation of a pipeline or part of a pipeline.
Pipeline Segment is approved, constructed, licensed and carrying substance.

Pipeline has been approved for construction, and may or may not be constructed and/or operating. Permitted status stays as such for one year after approval for construction has been given. Construction must begin within that time frame.
Pipelines to be removed or partially removed, including crossings of roads, railways, and watercourses.

attr.attrdef: A sequential number that uniquely identifies the legal subdivision where a pipeline segment's starting point is located.
The type of facility attached to the start of the pipeline segment.
The type of facility attached to the end of a pipeline segment.
The volume of Hydrogen Sulfide in cubic meters that could be released to atmosphere from a pipeline segment in the event of a release of fluid from the pipeline.

There are specific setback distances between pipelines containing gas or oil effluent > 10 mol/kmol H2S and permanent dwellings, unrestricted country developments, urban centres, or public facilities. These setback distances are grouped into levels based on the H2S release volume.
Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) content of a substance.
A sequential number that uniquely identifies the legal subdivision where a pipeline segment's end point is located.
The technical standard to which a pipeline is or will be constructed
Outside diameter of a pipeline in millimetres.
Wall thickness of a pipe in millimetres.

The CSA, API or ASTM standards for pipe manufacture.A defined set of values do not exist for this value. A reference table R_Pipe_Type is close, but not complete. An FK relationship did not work for the business and was removed.

The pipe grade, alloy or compound specification.A defined set of values do not exist for this value. A reference table R_Pipe_Grade is close, but not complete. An FK relationship did not work for the business and was removed.
Material from which the pipeline is manufactured.
A flag (Yes) indicating that the pipeline allows for flow in either direction.

A flag (Yes) indicating that the pipeline crosses a watercourse that appears on the OneStop Map Viewer and where construction methods at that watercourse crossing will use horizontal directional drilling or boring.
The grade of a freestanding pressure containing pipe that has been installed in an existing pipeline.
The type of a freestanding pressure containing pipe that has been installed in an existing pipeline.
The type of external coating for the pipe.
An indicator that the pipeline crosses a lake (LC), river (RC) or creek (CC) that appears on the 1:1,000,000 scale Alberta Base Plan Map.

The class location as defined in CSA Z662 – Oil and Gas Pipeline Systems, is a geographical area classified according to its approximate population density and other characteristics that are considered when designing and pressure testing piping to be located in the area.
Maximum operating pressure of the pipe.
Stress level of a pipe expressed as percent % of yield strength.
Method of Internal Protection
Method for joining lengths of pipe.

A substance that is used by or results from petroleum and natural gas operations.
Note: If the pipeline segment carries multiple substances, the highest priority substance will be applied.

edom.edomvd: Natural Gas with >10 mol/kmol of H2S content
Butane, ethylene, propane, pentanes, liquid ethane
Condensate, diesel fuel, gasoline, heating oil, hydrocarbons diluents, kerosene, solvents
Blended crude bitumen, crude oil, synthetic crude oil
Multiphase fluids
Methane, natural gas with <= 10 mol/kmol of H2S content
Fuel gas
Produced Water
Ammonia, caustic, glycol, methanol, polymer, sulphur, carbon dioxide
Air, ammonia, carbon dioxide, ethane, helium, hydrogen, nitrogen, steam
Potable water, surface water

attr.attrdef: Name of field center. An AER field centre is an AER centre that is located in an area of the province and is staffed to do the following for that area of the province: - provide 24 hour response to emergency, release, and complaint incidents; - inspect operations at wells, pipelines, and facilities in that area to ensure compliance with acts and regulations; - participate in public-industry liaison committees and facilitate the resolution of landowner-industry conflicts; and - answer information requests from the public
The original licence number for the segment. This is used to track the original licence where a segment is transferred to another licence.
The original segment specification id. This is used to track the original licence data where a segment is transferred to another licence.
The original segment line number for the segment. This is used to track the original licence where a segment is transferred to another licence.
The original date the segment was licensed. This is used to track the original licence where a segment has been transferred to another licence.
The original date the segment was licensed. This is used to track the original licence where a segment is transferred to another licence.
Date on which construction approval was granted.

The date that the segment or installation will convert from "Permitted" status to "Operating" status, normally one year from the permit date. Currently only used for new construction, may be used for amendment applications at some future date.
Year of last construction, test or status change.
The source of the geometry for the feature.

edom.edomvd: Pipeline drawings created during the planning stage
Construction drawings generated in support of Pipeline construction
Pipeline drawings depicting the actual location of the pipeline infrastructure post construction
Location of the pipeline as defined by the Centre of the Right of Way
AER manipulated Spatial Data in support of Base Plan products

attr.attrdef: Indicates a temporary line that is built on the surface and has a surface indicator of surface (SC) or overhead (OC)
